issue.title: Transformers refactor

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is a draft PR with a skeleton base class in accordance with the proposed refactor in STEP 11 here: https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/blob/main/steps/11_transformer_refactor/step.md
Functionality/logic is still missing, but this is for discussing the class design.

Main changes:
* nested `_fit`/`fit` logic as in forecasting and classification
* there is now just one base class; behaviour is controlled by the tags which indicate what input is converted in what output
* all transformers functions now accept series and panels; for instance, if it's a series-to-sth transformer, the panel instances are looped over. If it's a panel-to-sth transformer, a series is interpreted as a one-instance-panel.
* to enable this, the arguments need to change to be the same - `Z` will be deprecated in favour of `X` which anyway seems to be the key user expectation here; currently an input handler ensures that `Z` is treated as an alias for `X` in general

This PR also contains a first stab at:
* checking and conversion logic
* logic related to the panel/series treatment in one, single interface

As an example, I've also moved `BoxCoxTransformer` to the new interface:
* all that had to be done was changing `fit` to `_fit` etc, and populate the `X_inner_mtype` tag correctly
* due to the panel/series logic, this now also works out-of-the box for all the supported panel mtypes including `df-multiindex` which is used for hierarchical time series as well

Reviewers should focus on:
* the new transformers base class in `base.py`, especially the input handling logic
* the refactored `BoxCoxTransformer`, an example how a `SeriesToSeriesTransformer` looks after the refactor
* the refactored `SignatureTransformer`, an example how a `PanelToTabularTransformer` looks after the refactor

Minor changes needed to make the refactor work:
* conversion functionality from `Series` to `Panel` (one-instance) in `datatypes._series_as_panel`
* conversion from `Panel` mtype `nested_univ` from and to `df-list` (in `datatypes._panel._convert`), since the former is used a lot in tests
* added check in `check_is` for `pd.Dataframe` mtype for `Series` scitype for columns not of `object` dtype, since current check could not distinguish that and the `Panel` mtype `nested_univ` (both were `pd.DataFrame` type)
* PR #1368, which fixes an issue with `TrendForecaster` where it breaks if an `X` is passed. I've made a separate PR since it's a bug that's not related to transformers, just prevents proper fixing of another bug in the current transformer interface.
* `fit_transform` is changed to `fit(X, y).transform(X, y)` from `fit(X, y).transform(X)` which I think was an oversight. Since many tests use `TrendForecaster`, the above change #1368 has to be done first.
* changes to the signature transformers to address the interface inconsistency reported in #1369
* relaxing `np.ndarray` mtype for `Series` so 1D numpy arrays are also allowed (and considered univariate series or vector). This is required since some tests use univariate numpy arrays as label vectors.
* `ForecastingPipeline` was accidentally referring to `y` as `X` in one instance, this was fixed

body:
Sorry, I'm used to writing (data, labels) rather than (X, y) and evidently, I missed this. 

Are my tests supposed to have picked this up, or existing sktime tests?

>Are my tests supposed to have picked this up, or existing sktime tests?

The generic tests should probably have picked this up, so I'm worried that they didn't.
The transformer is correctly added in `_config`, so there must be a problem with the tests.

I've now pushed some tentative updates to the signature method as part of #1365 (using the conversion machinery since you need numpy 3D inside), would you mind having a look at the signature module therein?

It shouldn't have been necessary to change any of the transformers other than `SignatureTransformer` and `SignatureClassifier`. None of the other transform methods are ever used by anything other than within those classes so it shouldn't have mattered that they did not have the `y=None` argument for example. 

The only issue seems to be incorrect naming of `data, labels` rather than `X, y` which are just positional arguments so I don't see why they would have been picked up in tests as they are essentially stylistic. Unless something did
```
args = {'X': X, 'y': y}
transform(**args)
```
which I assume the tests don't do.

>It shouldn't have been necessary to change any of the transformers other than SignatureTransformer and SignatureClassifier. None of the other transform methods are ever used by anything other than within those classes so it shouldn't have mattered that they did not have the y=None argument for example.

No, it does matter, because the `sklearn` `pipeline` calls `fit_transform`, which in turn calls `transform(X, y)`, which for some reason passes a `y`, which breaks the transform elements.

I didn't follow exactly through the logic, but if you could track it down and provide an alternative fix, I wouldn't mind if you would revert changes, as long as it doesn't break things.
Ok, I see. That's very weird though. sklearns pipeline does not require a `y` argument to be in the `transform` method (even for `fit_transform`) unless this is a new thing?

issue.title: [BUG] esig is missing from "all extras" installs

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
`esig` seems to be missing from the "all extras" installs, which causes test errors in the development version, for instance.

Should it be not part of the `setup.py`?

@jambo6, @mloning, @aiwalter, @freddyaboulton, @corvusrabus, FYI

Of course, we should first fix issues with the signature methods, see here #1369.

body: Something ends up calling the `sktime` transformer which has a `y`, one would have to look at the trace back of what happens if you remove the change in the signatures files.
This was solved in the transformers refactor, PR #1365.
